subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{liushu|i}}: a line [[above]] another (contrast {{l|zh|ä¸‹}}) â€” [[up]]. Originally written as {{zh-l|ğ „}}, but changed to this form to prevent confusion with {{zh-l|äºŒ}}.

subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
From {{der|zh|sit}}. Cognate with {{cog|bo|à½¡à½„à¼‹à½¢à¾©à½º||summit; pinnacle}} ({{zh-ref|Bodman, 1980}}), {{cog|lus|zo||to be high}}, {{m|lus|zah||to respect; to revere}}.

''[[w:Shijing|Shijing]]'' rimes indicate occasional level tone for pronunciation 2 ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).

Pronunciation 1 is the exopassive of pronunciation 2 with suffix ''*-s'', literally meaning "what has been raised" ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}). The rising tone in Middle Chinese words with voiced stop initials regularly evolves into departing tone in Mandarin; pronunciation 3 results from {{zh-l|å¶éŸ»}}, which artificially preserves classical poetry rhyming words' pronunciations.
